content.description: Climb the obvious "V Groove" using the hand crack on the left wall.  For added challenge try not to use the opposing wall.
content.location: Look for the v-groove on the far right-hand side of the cliff. Almost the furthest route on the right.
On the extreme right side of cliff 10' to the right of the obvious The V-Groove

content.description: A fun little crack in a water groove. The crux is at the start then nice stemming and jams to the trees.
content.location: An unmistakeable water groove with a crack located near the left end of the crag.Â

content.description: This climb is located where the approach trail meets the cliff. A hard start that keeps getting harder with erosion leads to easier jamming above.
Locate a thin crack going up a shallow groove.Placng the gear is harder than it looks!Pitch 1: Hard moves to start, then climb the crack past a bolt to the top.
content.protection: no bolts. no anchor.  Use the pine tree at the top.
content.location: One of the farthest left climbs on the crag. Just above a small slab.

content.description: This route climbs the steep bolted face just left of a dirty rotten corner. Climb the steep pumpy face on big holds. Make a delicate mantle to the trees above.
A right to left slanting finger crack.
content.location: One of the last climbs on the crag's right side. 5' left of The V-Groove.

content.description: A right facing corner with 2 parallel cracks.
content.location: On the right side of the crag. Look for a right facing corner/dike.

content.description:
Climb over a block to the start of the climb. From there, you will find a nice crack to the left of the corner and a second thinner crack that forms the corner itself. Climb these, protecting where necessary, up to the block that forms a roof. Go around the block and over the birch tree, then through the remaining blocks at the top. The very top can be dirty and covered in lichen and pine needles, so be careful when walking off. 

  This is an interesting 5.6, because it is slightly overhung, but all of the handholds are large and solid. Feet can be a little tricky to find and can require a little balancing work.
content.protection: Standard medium sized cams work well and the crack to the right will take large nuts. A sling is useful for protecting off the birch tree the route is named after. Build your own anchor off trees at the top using static, as suitable anchor trees are a bit away from the edge. There is no hardware of any kind on this route.
content.location: This route is located near the middle of the wall that makes the crag, right where the approach trail Ts to go either direction. A quick look around will tell you you are in the right place, as the only routes to either side are 5.10+ to 5.12+.

content.description: A short, forested area tucked into the woods just above West Side Rd in North Conway.  Routes vary from traditional slab to very steep sport and mixed routes.  A great place for moderate top-roping with easy access to the top of the cliff and many trees for anchors.
